executive_summary: Over the past five years, concerns over a pilot shortage have impacted aviation industries. Airlines worry they can't replace retiring pilots, and early retirements amid COVID-19 pushed these issues to the center of discussion. Meanwhile, the industry's largest union has argued shortages result from low salaries and poor practices, not a lack of pilots. Regardless, airlines grounded nearly a quarter of all flights as a result of staffing issues in 2023. Rising demand for domestic and international travel is perpetuating the shortage as airlines seek to expand operations and drive ticket sales. Pilot salaries are on the rise as employers seek to attract new pilots, leading to heightened enrollment for flying schools. Revenue has been climbing at a CAGR of 3.7% to an estimated $5.5 billion over the five years through 2024, including a rise of 3.2% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Major airlines have been concerned about a pilot shortage for over a decade
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Airlines aren't allowed to employ pilots over 65 years of age, and forced retirement policies create attrition that many worry isn't adequately replenished by new pilots. These concerns surged as many pilots retired early amid the COVID-19 pandemic's effect on passenger air transport.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Air Line Pilots Association (ALPA) Int'l, the nation's largest pilot union, strongly disagrees
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The ALPA alleges meager salaries and unsafe practices as the reason for fewer pilots, citing Bureau of Labor Statistics data indicating the US may have more pilots than demand necessitates.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Regardless, these concerns continue to play a role in aviation
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Flight training company Flex Air reports that nearly a quarter of all flights in 2023 were grounded because of staffing issues. Airlines are responding by raising salaries to attract more pilots and return to maximum capacity. As high salaries and open positions make careers in aviation more attractive, flying schools enjoy rising enrollment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Flying Schools Will Be Be Primarily Responsible For Addressing the Worsening Pilot Shortage
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The pilot shortage is expected to get worse through the next period. Boeing's latest estimate (2024) expects steadily rising demand to create 127,000 new pilot jobs by 2042, but the current trajectory is set to keep the supply of new pilots significantly behind new job creation. Pilot attrition will exacerbate issues as the massive Baby Boomer population reaches the mandatory retirement age of 65.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Shifting Regulations Will Have a Mixed Effect on Flying Schools
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The latest FAA Reauthorization Act is expected to become law later in 2024, providing new funding to the industry's main regulator. This Act will expand training program requirements for air traffic controllers, air tour operators and airline professionals who assist passengers with mobility issues. Heightened requirements will boost time in flying school, driving up prices and revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Flying Schools Will Help Airlines Serve Demand for International Travel
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As disposable incomes climb, consumers will take more trips. Both domestic and international trips taken will climb over the next five years, bolstering demand for capable pilots. International travel is set to grow faster than domestic travel, indicating air transit's essential role in recreation and business.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition Will Constrain Prices and Profit
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the pilot shortage persists, new flying schools will open and push up the industry's fragmentation. This saturation will create an intensified competitive atmosphere. Both professional and hobbyist aviation enthusiasts will have more options to choose from when seeking a flying school. Price will be a major sticking point, and flying schools will be under pressure to offer competitive tuition.

industry_definition: This industry provides instruction in piloting, aircraft operation and related areas. These schools leverage simulation and in-air training methods to offer a range of programs, including private pilot, commercial pilot and airline transport pilot certifications.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - steady

key_trends: Flying schools compete mainly on tuition and links with major airlines. To soften the competition, some schools focus on improving their reputation or forming ties with airlines.
Mergers and acquisitions are uncommon. Localized demand means each school targets and serves its immediate area, and high capital requirements stifle international expansion.

Airlines are struggling to keep their planes staffed. Staffing issues forced airlines to ground nearly a quarter of all flights in 2023, leading to salary hikes to attract new pilots. Flying schools are seeing heightened enrollment as aviation careers become more lucrative.

Consumers and businesses will take more trips as disposable income and corporate profit climb, airlines will see heightened demand. Pilots will be a necessity for airlines to expand their flight offerings.
Three companies control a third of the industry. Most aviation enthusiasts aren't willing to relocate to attend a flying school, so demand is heavily localized.

Flying schools are heavily regulated and receive little government assistance. FAA is the primary regulatory body that governs flying schools. Most of the FAA's Aviation Workforce Development Grants go to competing colleges or universities.
Flight schools heavily rely on well-compensated instructors. Over a quarter of the industry's revenue goes to wages, as instructors' training and certification costs often exceed $100,000.

It's expensive to purchase, store and maintain aircraft. Flying schools need a variety of planes for different certification programs. Rent and upkeep, including securing qualified mechanics for regular maintenance, also drive up expenses.
Flying schools are typically close to metropolitan and popular regional airport hubs. States with significant military bases also draw flying schools for military aviation training.

Weather plays a role in the industry's dispersion. Sunny skies in states like Florida, California and Texas make it much easier for flying schools to take flight, making them popular locations for the industry.

Students under 25 are becoming a larger market for the industry. Ballooning student debt is making many recent high school graduates skeptical of college, leading them to pursue flying school and other vocational schools.

Commercial pilot certificates are by far the industry's most lucrative. While flying schools award more ATP and private certifications, commercial certificates' heavy price tag makes them the industry's top product segment.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Students under 25 are becoming a larger market for the industry. Ballooning student debt is making many recent high school graduates skeptical of college, leading them to pursue flying school and other vocational schools. These individuals have little disposable income. Hobby aviation is nearly nonexistent within this demographic, as most teenagers and young adults can't afford to fly for fun.

Pilot shortages are making an aviation career more attractive to those already settled into other jobs. As workers in other industries faced pandemic-era layoffs, many decided to pursue a career as a pilot instead. With more financial stability compared to younger individuals, those in this age group can better afford the cost of flight training.

Interest in commercial aviation falls off as consumers age into this demographic. Most individuals between 45 and 65 have extensive experience in another career, so switching to aviation means giving up skills and credibility in another field. Still, individuals in this age have higher disposable income. Many also look to pick up new hobbies at this age, leading this market to remain a prominent revenue stream for the industry.

By law, no air carrier can use the services of any pilot aged 65 and older, limiting its contribution to revenue. Still, persons over 65 may pursue certificates for flying nonscheduled air carriers. These include personal, recreational and sport aircraft. The growing elderly population in the United States has contributed to this segment's growth in the share of total revenue during the current period. As individuals can stay active longer, many have taken to less traditional leisure activities, including flying. This age bracket is also typically wealthier than those under 24, permitting this segment to spend more on recreational activities. Older adults are also less influenced by trends in the unemployment rate, given that they aren't typically part of the labor force anymore.

FAQs.answer: Rising discretionary incomes are expected to benefit the industry, as those interested in acquiring a pilot's license for recreational use are more likely to enroll in the industry's more costly classes.
